awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Multi-Dimensional Nano-Characterization System Based on a Scanning Probe Microscope for Multidisciplinary Materials Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description:
A scanning probe microscope (SPM) is a scientific instrument that uses a sharp probe to measure surface and interface properties in nanometer and sub-nanometer spatial resolution. The SPM system acquired through this Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award has significant impact on the research, education, and training infrastructure at Rowan University and its surrounding area in southern New Jersey. First, this instrument enables collaborative materials research among faculty members, undergraduate and graduate students, and regional industrial participants to conduct ground-breaking research. It allows the establishment of inter- and intra-institutional research collaborations. Second, this instrument helps grow several programs, such as the Materials Science & Engineering program, by providing ample opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students to work on their research projects, coursework, or thesis projects, directly impacting the training of a technical workforce for the region. Third, this instrument is used by many researchers including women and underrepresented minority faculty and students through established university and college programs. This provides better experience, stronger training, and more opportunities for researchers from groups typically underrepresented in science and engineering. Finally, this instrument serves the local needs in advanced materials research and training, resulting in increased interactions with local industries and stronger impact on the economic growth in the region.

Technical Description:
The acquired SPM system combines ultrahigh-resolution imaging, nanoelectrical measurement, nanomechanical characterization, and nanoelectrochemical analysis for the research of various material systems in air, fluid, electrical field, or chemically reactive environment. With these advanced features, the instrument enables research projects in five key research areas: (1) surface morphology and nanomaterials research; (2) functional materials, flexible electronics and sensors; (3) electrochemistry, energy materials and devices, and protective coatings; (4) biological and biomedical materials, life sciences; and (5) additive manufacturing, construction and structural materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview: In 2021, the NSF MRI grant (2116353) was conferred to a dedicated team of researchers at Rowan University. The purpose was clear: to procure a state-of-the-art scanning probe microscope (SPM) to bolster multidisciplinary materials research and education.

Achievements and Impact (9/1/2021 - 8/31/2023):

1. Infrastructure & Collaboration: The Bruker's Dimension XR SPM system, which was acquired, has set a new benchmark in research capabilities, including PeakForce Tapping, DataCube modes, SECM, and AFM-nDMA at Rowan University. It facilitated inter-college collaborations, fostered cross-campus interactions, and was a catalyst for several new graduate programs, including Materials Science and Engineering, Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Civil Engineering, Biomedical Engineering, and Electrical & Computer Engineering.
2. Inclusion: The project made notable strides in increasing the participation of women and underrepresented minority (URM) students and faculty in STEM disciplines. Through initiatives like ACS SEED, NSF RED, and ASCEND, URM students gained hands-on exposure to the SPM, enriching their academic pursuits.
3. Training & Education: Over 200 students annually benefit from the SPM's integration into the curriculum. Extensive eleven-day training sessions, spanning three visits, were facilitated by Bruker's experts, equipping faculty, staff, and students with the needed expertise. Future users will also benefit from meticulously crafted SPM user guides with visuals.
4. Research Prowess: In the short span since its installation, the SPM has catalyzed groundbreaking research activities. This is evident in the publication of four peer-reviewed articles and ten noteworthy presentations. It's not just an instrument, but an integral part of advanced research, and many more contributions to the world of materials science are anticipated.
5. Community Engagement: Rowan University opened its doors, allowing students and faculty from neighboring institutions and industrial collaborators to access the SPM. This step fostered a spirit of knowledge-sharing and collaborative endeavor.
6. Future Prospects: The SPM promises to be a linchpin in future research endeavors, especially for junior faculty across diverse disciplines. Master's and Ph.D. students are already leveraging it for their theses, demonstrating its long-term academic importance.

Conclusion: The acquisition and integration of the SPM at Rowan University have not only enriched the immediate academic and research landscape but promise lasting impacts. As the university forges ahead, the SPM will be instrumental in addressing pivotal challenges in materials research like climate change, the energy crisis, and societal sustainability.

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2023
Modified by: Ping Lu
